 The FBI's preliminary statistics could ease concerns that gangs, youth violence, more gun crimes and fewer police could lead to a long-term rise in crime.

I'm back, and I want to get into the discussion about sales, tracing, and registration. Sinjin I've read what you have posted, and I want to reply to some of it.
 
 
 Traceable to the manufacturer, not the retail purchaser. So you could go buy any number of them and give them to all your criminal friends and no one would ever know. 

 
 
 My understanding is that they run a background check to see if you can legally buy, that's all. Is that incorrect? Question- In Texas, do they record the purchasers info and tie it to the serial numbers of the purchased weapons(say rifles for instance)? Wouldn't that be like registration, which they don't do? 

 
 The original purchaser is always recorded. All dealers are required to maintain records on site of all sales from which the purchaser can be identified. The record is really a copy of the federal firearms transaction form you fill out when you purchase a gun. The form has all the purchaser information required at the sale (name, address, SS#, DoB, form of photo ID used). The form also records the weapon sold by manufacturer, model, caliber, and serial number. These records are required to be kept forever and may be inspected by BATFE. If a dealer goes out of business then he must send all these records to BATFE for safe-keeping. It is a dispersed form of registration which permits law enforcement investigation without abandoning the legitimate privacy rights of individual citizens.
 
 The trace we do now happens like this. We have to first recover a gun. We contact BATFE and give them the manufacturer/model/serial number. BATFE then contacts the manufacturer, which tells BATFE which dealer the gun was shipped to and when. BATFE then contacts the dealer to determine who bought the gun. The dealer gives BATFE the name, address, SS#, DoB, etc. he recorded for the sale. All this info gets reported to the LE agency who requested the trace, and the local agency takes over the investigation from there.
 
 This system does not track secondary market sales/transfers between private individuals. It is entirely possible that a gun recovered at a murder scene would have been bought from a dealer 20 years ago, then stolen from that owner, then sold to someone else who did not know it was stolen, then traded to another person for a guitar, then later sold to the murder suspect. We have no effective method of following these transfers after a gun is stolen. 
 
 Criminal prosecution is not based upon ownership of a gun, however. It is based upon possession or use. That requires evidence which a trace does not provide. Sometimes a trace tells us the gun we found was purchased 20 years ago in another state by someone who is already dead. Sometimes the trace tells us the gun was purchased by the suspect's girlfriend six months ago. In the latter instance the trace could lead us to a possible witness against a suspect. But in all cases the trace is nothing more than background info which helps the investigation. It is rarely, if ever, relevant evidence for prosecution. In a murder case, for example, we have to find the gun first and link it to the crime. We then have to link the gun to the suspect. Trace date is only marginally relevant in proving this link. I don't care who bought the gun 20 years ago. What matters is can I put the gun in the hands of a suspect on the day the murder happened. The more relevant questions are: Was the gun found on him or in something he controls (his book bag, car, or house)? Are the suspect's prints or DNA on the gun? Does the suspect have gunshot residue on his hands? Did the suspect have ammunition in his pocket that fit the gun, etc.? These questions cannot be answered by a gun trace, no matter how accurate.

However, In the 1990's, Charles Schemer was fond of saying that even pro-gun people are calling for more gun laws, which was absolutely true, before the Anti-gun side went crazy and started disrespected both us and our Constitution and our Constitutional Process. 
 
 We tried to work with our Fellow citizens and give them a few laws even though we were pretty sure they would not work! Back then, Sarah Brady would constantly say, paraphrased, "We know you have a Constitutional Right." "But all we are asking for is a background check when someone buys a handgun." "Nothing More!" So we gave in on that and a bunch more to boot. Are you satisfied? Do you respect us for allowing these infringements? I say No!

Lets recount the number of gun laws again. 20 to 30 thousand gun laws in America. 

 
We can do this dance till the cows come home and it won't mean a thing if the lwas in one state can be circumvented by driving to another.

 This is a Constitutionally recognized as protected Right we are talking about. The bare minimum is all we are supposed to ask of our Constitutional Rights. This isn't just some regular product that you are trying to control. And, I might add, that you are trying your very best to control We the People as well. That is also supposed to be Constitutionally beyond Your Control! The Constitution is the Supreme Law of the Land! But, if you ask me, you guys don't seem care a bit if that law gets violated. Just as long as you get all of the gun control laws you want! And THAT (Messing with what the Constitution means, and who and what it protects) is a very serious Crime in my books. 
 
 Brian already talked about the Criminals and what is valuable to the Justice System so that stands supreme as he is the expert in the field, so I will leave the rest of your post to what he said. 
 
 Criminal prosecution is not based upon ownership of a gun, however. It is based upon possession or use.
 
 But in all cases the trace is nothing more than background info which helps the investigation. It is rarely, if ever, relevant evidence for prosecution. In a murder case, for example, we have to find the gun first and link it to the crime. We then have to link the gun to the suspect. Trace date is only marginally relevant in proving this link. I don't care who bought the gun 20 years ago. What matters is can I put the gun in the hands of a suspect on the day the murder happened. The more relevant questions are: Was the gun found on him or in something he controls (his book bag, car, or house)? Are the suspect's prints or DNA on the gun? Does the suspect have gunshot residue on his hands? Did the suspect have ammunition in his pocket that fit the gun, etc.? These questions cannot be answered by a gun trace, no matter how accurate.

 I guess if one argues a point long enough, even though it is a Constitutional Right, it soon becomes like watching the beating of Rodney King when they were analyzing each blow. Pretty soon the viewer becomes numb to the fact that a crime is taking place.
 
   U.S. Code as of: 01/19/04 Section 1983. Civil action for deprivation of rights 
 Every person who, under color of any statute, ordinance, regulation, custom, or usage, of any State or Territory or the District of Columbia, subjects, or causes to be subjected, any citizen of the United States or other person within the jurisdiction thereof to the deprivation of any rights, privileges, or immunities secured by the Constitution and laws, shall be liable to the party injured in an action at law, suit in equity, or other proper proceeding for redress, except that in any action brought against a judicial officer for an act or omission taken in such
 officer's judicial capacity, injunctive relief shall not be granted unless a declaratory decree was violated or declaratory relief was unavailable. For the purposes of this section, any Act of Congress applicable exclusively to the District of Columbia shall be considered to be a statute of the District of Columbia.

 
   Color of Law 
 Preventing abuse of this authority, however, is equally necessary to the health of our nation's democracy. That's why it's a federal crime for anyone acting under "color of law" willfully to deprive or conspire to deprive a person of a right protected by the Constitution or U.S. law. "Color of law" simply means that the person is using authority given to him or her by a local, state, or federal government agency.
Bryan

Wouldn't requiring the recording of all subsequent transfers of ownership assist LE investigations? 

 
 Yes. More information is always better than less. Having a better ability to “walk out to the end of the possession chain” of a recovered firearm would help narrow the list of suspects and potentially provide witnesses who could say the ultimate suspect acquired the gun from them on X date. I’m not saying this information has no relevance, it is just far less important than some of the other facts I listed earlier. This also assumes, of course, that an effective scheme could be devised to record secondary market transfers. I know of no constitutionally permissible way to create such a scheme which could require felons and others who can’t have guns to register transfers they are involved in or guns they possess.
 
 
 And wouldn't that in conjunction with mandatory theft/loss reporting be even more helpful in identifying suspects and their associates? 

 
 Probably not. Mandatory theft/loss reporting only identifies when a gun was stolen—it does nothing to identify the thief. Larceny breaks the traceable chain of possession—whether or not a mandatory registration of possession/transfer law exists. The thief will not want to register the gun he just stole. And he cannot be required to register his newly acquired possession of the gun, nor will he be required to register a subsequent sale/transfer of the stolen gun. To make him do so would unconstitutionally force him to incriminate himself in the larceny/possession of stolen property crime. I also doubt a new purchaser from the thief would record his possession/purchase—even if he could otherwise lawfully possess the gun. Say A has a gun stolen by B, who then offers to sell it to C. If C says “OK let’s register the transfer and my new possession as the law directs” then B will say no and keep the gun—and the gun stays off the database. If C agrees to buy the gun without registering the transfer, then he has chosen to violate the mandatory registration rules, and he will not later register the gun possession and expose himself to prosecution for failing to register the his original purchase from B. C will, like B, keep the gun to himself and off the registration database unless he finds a Mr. D who will also agree to purchase the gun on the illegal secondary market. Once the gun is stolen it will stay out of the registration database unless and until law enforcement recovers it and returns it to Mr. A.
 
 Let me address the home inspection requirement issue for a moment. 4th. amendment case law strikes a balance between the legitimate need of the government’s investigation against the strength of the privacy interest involved. There is a sliding scale of allowable government intrusion based in large part on the legitimate privacy interests involved—which will vary depending on the location and/or things to be searched. 
 
 I have written several search warrants for homes in my career. A home is the most difficult place to obtain judicial permission to search by law enforcement because (rightly, in my opinion) SCOTUS has long declared that a man’s home is where he enjoys the greatest “expectation of privacy.” For example, if you have probable cause to believe that both a stopped car and a home have marijuana stored inside them, then you can immediately search the car without a warrant but must obtain a warrant to search the home because the expectation of privacy in a car is far less than that of a home. 
 
 If we are talking about requiring home inspections for gun ownership then in my opinion we are allowing the government to arbitrarily invade the most securely private area a man possesses—without the slightest suspicion or even inference against him of having committed an offense. 
 
 In my opinion it would also be bad public policy to create this home invasion permission exception because it would surely have a chilling effect on the free exercise of a protected right—not unlike the chilling effect that would descend on the free exercise of religion from making a bad proposal to have home inspections of known Islamic fundamentalists to ensure they are not making homemade IEDs. In addition, a home inspection scheme would create an Orwellian reality whereby “all citizens rights are equal, but some are more equal than others”—that the government is allowed to believe a gun owner’s right to privacy in his home is less than non-gun owner’s—despite the due process/equal protection provisions of the constitution—and all merely because one of the two chooses to exercise a protected constitutional right. 
 
 Now maybe there are non-gun owners out there who say “sure, go ahead and do it, it will not affect me.” For those who would say this, let me ask this question: What happens later when an overeager politician uses the firearm home inspection rule as justification for demanding that you also open your home to random inspection of some item you have which he does not like?
